title: Take Glencore Private If Market Unfair, Citi Says With `Buy' - Yahoo Finance
text:
Glencore Plc, the commodity trader whose shares lost almost a third of their value in a day, just got a vote of confidence from Citigroup Inc.
The company doesn’t have a stressed balance sheet, has the ability to sell assets to stem the rout and is rated as a “ buy,” according to the New York-based bank. And if the stock extends losses, management should simply take it private, Citigroup said in a report.
“The markets response is overdone,” Citigroup said. “In the event the equity market continues to express its unwillingness to value the business fairly, the company management should take the company private, whereby restructuring measures can be taken easily and quickly.”
More from Bloomberg.com: Glencore in Freefall as Analysts See Tougher Restructuring 
Glencore sank to a record in Hong Kong on Tuesday following the 29 percent plunge in London amid concern that the company’s debt load may be excessive as commodity prices sink. While Investec Plc said on Monday that there would be little left for Glencore’s shareholders should the low prices persist, Citigroup said that even with copper at $4,000 a metric ton and other raw material prices stable, Glencore would post earnings before interest, taxes and amortization of about $7.5 billion.
Stake SaleGlencore has hired Citigroup and Credit Suisse Group AG to sell a minority stake in its agricultural business, a person familiar with the situation said Friday. The planned sale is part of a debt-cutting program announced earlier this month that included selling $2.5 billion of new stock in an attempt to trim the company’s debt to $20 billion from $30 billion.
More from Bloomberg.com: NASA Detects Liquid Water on Mars 
“The group is not limited to just selling a minority stake and if the need be, the entire agricultural-marketing business could be sold, which we value at about $10.5 billion,” Citigroup said in the report on Monday. “The level of interest is likely to be high.”
A downgrade of Glencore’s credit rating to sub-investment standard is unlikely, Citigroup said. And should a downgrade happen, Glencore’s counter parties probably wouldn’t stop trading with the company, it said.
More from Bloomberg.com: Saudi Arabia Withdrew Billions From Markets, Estimates Show 
The Hong Kong-traded shares in the Zug, Switzerland-based trader dived as much as 30 percent to HK$8.61 on Tuesday, and were at HK$8.91 at 2 p.m. local time. In London, Glencore’s stock closed on Monday at 68.6 pence compared with Citigroup’s target price of 170 pence.
Peter Grauer, the chairman of Bloomberg LP, the parent of Bloomberg News, is a senior independent non-executive director at Glencore.
